author: pipermerriam
content: <@240180844130598912> given that there's been a few improvements to trin performance in the last weeks, have you experimented with turning all the state bridges back on again to see how the situation has improved?

author: kolbyml
content: What improvements are you referring to?

author: kolbyml
content: I already tested/deployed these and the Portal Nodes were still getting congested unfortunately (At least those are my assumptions, which can be confirmed* if we deploy Accept Codes)

author: pipermerriam
content: Ok, alternative option? Can you artificially slow down the rate at which the bridges process blocks? How slow do we have to be for things to work?

author: kolbyml
content: Is it fine if we try this after `Accept Codes` are deployed? Just because `Accept Codes` remove a lot of the guessing from knowing how our bridges perform.

author: kolbyml
content: I am fine running this experiment after `Accept Codes` are deployed, but it will likely be delayed due to requiring the `pv` rollout. Well `pv` has some initial cost, but after clients implement it it should be easier to ship changes in the future.

author: kolbyml
content: I remember now, these performance improvements increase the performance of Block Bodies and Receipts on the history network, but not Headers. So these changes wouldn't really make a different for the State Network. There seems to be a bottleneck around initializing the offer/accept, because Trin is able to send Bodies and Receipts so much faster after those fixes above
